li.p: For positive integers m and n, \sqrt[n]{x^m}=x^{\sfrac{m}{n}}. This is universally true when x is positive. When x is negative, things are more complicated. It boils down to a choice. Some computer algebra systems choose to define an expression like (-8)^{\sfrac{1}{3}} as a certain negative real number (-2). Others choose to define an expression like (-8)^{\sfrac{1}{3}} as a complex number in the upper half plane of the complex plane (1+i\sqrt{3}). Because of the ambiguity, some choose to simply declare expressions like (-8)^{\sfrac{1}{3}}, with a negative base, to be undefined. The point is, if your computer tells you that say, (-8)^{\sfrac{1}{3}} is undefined, you should realize that you may be expected to interpret (-8)^{\sfrac{1}{3}} as -2.
